title: Episode 1-3 Highlights | Chaebol Son-in-law Kim Soo-hyun Finally Decides to Divorce—But Then a Huge Problem Arises?!
synopsis: Baek Hyun-woo, exhausted from years of mistreatment by his in-laws, finally decides to divorce his cold wife Hong Hye-in. But just as he announces his decision, she reveals she only has three months to live.

contents.original: 스트레스가 상당하신 것 같은데 문진 와서 검사하신 걸 보면 지금 가장 하고 싶은 것은 이혼이다라고 하셨네요.
contents.pronunciation: Seuteureseu-ga sangdang-hasin geot gateunde munjin waseo geomsa-hasin geol bomyeon jigeum gajang hago sipeun geoseun ihon-ida-rago hasyeonneyo.
contents.translation: You seem quite stressed. Looking at your intake form, you wrote that what you want most right now is divorce.

grammar.example: 상당하신 것 같은데 = it seems quite significant
이혼이다라고 하셨네요 = you said it's divorce

contents.culture: This scene takes place in a counseling/therapy session. Seeking professional mental health help has become more accepted in Korea, though still carries some stigma.

contents.translation: Yes.
Is there a reason?

grammar.explanation: Polite question form expressing wonder or asking

contents.original: 저는 장인어른 장모님과 한 집에 살아요.
contents.pronunciation: Jeoneun jang-in-eoreun jangmonim-gwa han jib-e sarayo.
contents.translation: I live in the same house as my father-in-law and mother-in-law.
contents.culture: Living with in-laws is common in Korea, but typically with the husband's parents. Living with the wife's parents is unusual and suggests the husband married 'up' into a powerful family.

contents.translation: And the grandfather too.
The grandfather too?

contents.original: 얼마 전 출소하신 고모님이랑 친아내 가족까지 우린 모두 다 한 집에 살아요.
contents.pronunciation: Eolma jeon chulso-hasin gomonim-irang chin-anae gajok-kkaji urin modu da han jib-e sarayo.
contents.translation: Including my aunt who was recently released from prison and my wife's family—we all live together in one house.

grammar.explanation: Verb meaning 'to be released from prison'

contents.culture: Having a family member who went to prison is significant. In chaebol families, imprisonment often relates to financial crimes, embezzlement, or corruption.

contents.translation: Ah...
Looking at it this way, you have a big family. Blessed, shall we say?

grammar.explanation: Adjective meaning 'blessed with many family members'

contents.culture: 다복하다 traditionally means being blessed with many children/family. The counselor uses it somewhat ironically here.

contents.original: 너무 다복해서 매일 저녁 밥을 같이 먹고요.
contents.pronunciation: Neomu dabokhaeseo maeil jeonyeok bab-eul gachi meokgoyo.
contents.translation: So blessed that we eat dinner together every day.
contents.culture: Mandatory family dinners are common in traditional Korean households, especially wealthy ones, as a way to maintain family hierarchy and control.

contents.original: 9시쯤 되면 다 같이 모여서 얘기하는 시간도 있어요. 종례처럼요.
contents.pronunciation: Ahopsi-jjeum doemyeon da gachi moyeoseo yaegi-haneun sigan-do isseoyo. Jongnye-cheoreomyo.
contents.translation: Around 9 o'clock, we all gather to talk. Like a school homeroom meeting.
contents.culture: 종례 refers to the end-of-day homeroom meeting in Korean schools. Comparing family time to this suggests it feels mandatory and institutional rather than warm.

contents.original: 주말, 휴가, 생일, 크리스마스, 모든 걸 다 같이 하다 보면 1년 365일 제 시간은 없다고 보시면 돼요.
contents.pronunciation: Jumal, hyuga, saengil, Keuriseumaseu, modeun geol da gachi hada bomyeon ilnyeon sambaegyukship-oil je sigan-eun eopdago bosimyeon dwaeyo.
contents.translation: Weekends, vacations, birthdays, Christmas—doing everything together means I have no personal time 365 days a year.

grammar.explanation: Expression meaning 'if you keep doing/when you do'
grammar.example: 하다 보면 = when you keep doing

grammar.explanation: Polite way of saying 'you can consider it as'
grammar.example: 없다고 보시면 돼요 = you can consider it as having none

contents.translation: We have ancestral rites 15 times a year.
contents.culture: 15 ancestral rites per year is extremely excessive. Most Korean families hold 2-4 제사 annually. This highlights the family's obsession with tradition and status.

contents.original: 옛날에 진짜 양반가에서는 남자들이 다 제사 준비를 했다고 그러시면서 사위들한테 처음부터 끝까지 다 하라고 시키거든요.
contents.pronunciation: Yennar-e jinjja yangban-ga-eseoneun namja-deuri da jesa junbi-reul haetdago geureusimyeonseo sawideul-hante cheoeumbuteo kkeutkkaji da harago sikigeodeunyo.
contents.translation: They say in the old noble families, men did all the ancestral rite preparations, so they make the sons-in-law do everything from start to finish.

grammar.example: 하라고 시키거든요 = they make us do

contents.culture: This is the same justification from the previous clip—claiming 'noble tradition' to make sons-in-law do all the work while actual sons do nothing.

contents.original: 자기 아들들은 손에 물 한 방울 안 묻히게 하면서.
contents.pronunciation: Jagi adeul-deureun son-e mul han bangul an muchige hamyeonseo.
contents.translation: While making sure their own sons don't lift a finger.

grammar.pattern: 손에 물 한 방울 안 묻히다 (son-e mul han bangul an muchida)
grammar.explanation: Idiom meaning 'to not lift a finger/do any work'
grammar.example: 물 한 방울 안 묻히게 = without getting a drop of water on their hands

contents.original: 뭔가 숨통 트일 만한 곳이 필요하긴 한 상황이네요.
contents.pronunciation: Mwonga sumtong teuilmanhan gos-i pilyo-hagin han sanghwang-ineyo.
contents.translation: It does seem like you need somewhere to breathe.

grammar.explanation: Idiom meaning 'to be able to breathe/get relief'
grammar.example: 숨통 트일 만한 곳 = a place to breathe

contents.translation: Do you perhaps have a job?
Yes.
Good. How is your work life?
My boss is my wife.
contents.culture: Working under your spouse in a family company creates double pressure—professional and personal hierarchy overlap completely.

contents.translation: The boss above her is my father-in-law.

grammar.example: 그 위 상사 = the boss above

contents.translation: And the boss above him is the grandfather.

grammar.example: 그 위에 위 상사 = the boss above that

contents.culture: Three generations of in-laws as his superiors at work illustrates the complete entrapment—no escape at home or at work.

contents.original: 핸드폰에 처가 식구들 이름만 뜨면 심장이 뛰고 손이 떨려요.
contents.pronunciation: Haendeupon-e cheoga sikgu-deul ireum-man tteumyeon simjang-i ttwigo son-i tteollyeoyo.
contents.translation: When my in-laws' names appear on my phone, my heart races and my hands shake.

grammar.example: 이름만 뜨면 = as soon as the name appears

contents.original: 이번에는 또 무슨 일로 나를 부려먹을까 싶어서.
contents.pronunciation: Ibeon-eneun tto museun illo nareul buryeomeogeulkka sipeoseo.
contents.translation: Wondering what they'll make me do this time.

grammar.example: 부려먹을까 싶어서 = wondering if they'll exploit me

contents.original: 이 스트레스를 주는 환경에서 좀 벗어나 보는 건 어떨까요?
contents.pronunciation: I seuteuleseu-reul juneun hwangyeong-eseo jom beoseona boneun geon eotteolkkayo?
contents.translation: How about trying to get away from this stressful environment?

grammar.example: 벗어나 보는 건 = trying to get away

contents.translation: For that, the only answer is divorce.

grammar.example: 이혼밖에 답이 없어요 = divorce is the only answer

contents.translation: What about moving out separately?
contents.culture: 분가 means a married couple moving out from the extended family home to live independently—a reasonable suggestion the counselor makes.

contents.translation: Of course I dislike my in-laws too.

contents.original: 그런데 더 싫은 게 제 와이프예요.
contents.pronunciation: Geureonde deo sireun ge je waipeu-yeyo.
contents.translation: But what I dislike more is my wife.

grammar.example: 더 싫은 게 = what's more hateful is

contents.translation: Why?

contents.original: 내가 자기네 식구들한테 치이건 말건 밥을 먹건 말건 자기밖에 몰라요.
contents.pronunciation: Naega jagine sikgu-deul-hante chigeon malgeon bab-eul meokgeon malgeon jagi-bakke mollayo.
contents.translation: Whether I'm pushed around by her family or whether I eat or not, she only cares about herself.

grammar.example: 치이건 말건 = whether pushed around or not

contents.translation: She's really selfish.

contents.original: 내가 저 하나 보고 이 집에 와서 3년을 그 구박을 당했는데 그걸 나 몰라라 하고 결혼할 때는 뭐 자기만 믿으라고 그러더니.
contents.pronunciation: Naega jeo hana bogo i jib-e waseo samnyeon-eul geu gubak-eul danghaenneunde geugeol na mollara hago gyeolhonhal ttae-neun mwo jagi-man mideeurago geureodeoni.
contents.translation: I came to this house just for her and endured 3 years of mistreatment, but she ignored it all. When we got married, she told me to trust only her.

grammar.example: 저 하나 보고 = just for her

grammar.explanation: Idiom meaning 'to pretend not to know/ignore'

contents.translation: You just need to look at me.

grammar.example: 나만 보면 돼 = you just need to look at me

contents.translation: Just trust me.

contents.original: 나 절대 당신 눈에서 눈물 나게 안 해.
contents.pronunciation: Na jeoldae dangsin nun-eseo nunmul nage an hae.
contents.translation: I'll never make tears fall from your eyes.

grammar.example: 절대 안 해 = I absolutely won't

grammar.explanation: Causative expression meaning 'to make someone cry'
grammar.example: 눈물 나게 안 해 = won't make you cry

contents.culture: This promise contrasts with the drama's title '눈물의여왕' (Queen of Tears), adding dramatic irony.

contents.original: 그 마음을 믿은 내가 미친 놈이지만요.
contents.pronunciation: Geu ma-eum-eul mideun naega michin nom-ijimanyeo.
contents.translation: But I was the fool who believed that heart.

grammar.example: 미친 놈이지만요 = I'm the crazy one but

contents.translation: Are you feeling hurt by your wife?
contents.culture: 섭섭하다 describes a gentle sadness or disappointment, often from feeling neglected by someone close.

contents.original: 아니요. 이제는 섭섭하지도 않고 그 사람이 싫어요.
contents.pronunciation: Aniyo. Ije-neun seopseopaji-do anko geu saram-i sireoyo.
contents.translation: No. I'm not even hurt anymore—I just hate her.
I'm so sick of her I can't stand it.

grammar.explanation: Idiom meaning 'to be utterly disgusted/fed up'
grammar.example: 진절머리 나게 싫어요 = so disgusted I hate it

contents.translation: So that's why you want a divorce?

contents.original: 제가 살려면 그래야 할 것 같아요.
contents.pronunciation: Jega sallyeomyeon geureoya hal geot gatayo.
contents.translation: I think I need to do that to survive.

grammar.example: 살려면 = if I want to live
그래야 할 것 같아요 = I think I have to

contents.original: 그런데 왜 이혼을 안 하고 계세요?
contents.pronunciation: Geureonde wae ihon-eul an hago gyeseyo?
contents.translation: Then why haven't you divorced?

grammar.example: 안 하고 계세요 = are not doing (honorific)

contents.translation: Because I might end up dead.

grammar.example: 죽을 수도 있을 것 같아서요 = I feel like I might die

contents.translation: What?

grammar.explanation: Expression of surprise or asking to repeat

contents.original: 저희 장인어른은 자기 집 밥 먹던 사람이 등 보이는 걸 제일 싫어하시거든요.
contents.pronunciation: Jeohui jang-in-eoreun-eun jagi jip bap meokdeon saram-i deung boineun geol jeil sireohasi-geodeunyo.
contents.translation: My father-in-law hates it most when someone who ate at his table turns their back on him.

grammar.explanation: Literally 'eat rice' but means 'to be fed by/be part of'
grammar.example: 밥 먹던 사람 = someone who ate at his table

grammar.explanation: Idiom meaning 'to turn one's back on/betray'
grammar.example: 등 보이는 걸 = showing one's back

contents.culture: In Korean culture, 'eating someone's rice' implies owing loyalty. Leaving after 'eating their rice' is seen as betrayal, especially in traditional powerful families.

contents.original: 등을 보이는 순간 등 쪽에 칼이 꽂힐 거예요.
contents.pronunciation: Deung-eul boineun sungan deung jjok-e kal-i kkochil geoyeyo.
contents.translation: The moment I turn my back, a knife will be stuck in it.

grammar.example: 보이는 순간 = the moment I show

grammar.explanation: Expression meaning 'a knife gets stuck in'
grammar.example: 칼이 꽂힐 거예요 = a knife will be stuck

contents.translation: A knife?

grammar.explanation: Polite particle for emphasis or confirmation

contents.translation: Not a real knife, of course.

grammar.example: 진짜 칼은 아니고요 = it's not a real knife

contents.original: 그런데 진짜 칼이 나올 수도 있어요.
contents.pronunciation: Geureonde jinjja kal-i naol sudo isseoyo.
contents.translation: But a real knife could come out too.

grammar.example: 나올 수도 있어요 = might come out

contents.culture: This half-joke suggests the father-in-law's power and ruthlessness—chaebol families in dramas are often portrayed as capable of anything to protect their interests.

contents.original: 내가 안 그래도 너한테 한 소리 하고 싶었는데 너랑 올케 둘 다 어떻게 그럴 수가 있니?
contents.pronunciation: Naega an geuraedo neohante han sori hago sipeosseunde neorang olke dul da eotteoke geureol suga inni?
contents.translation: I've been wanting to say something to you. How could you and your sister-in-law both do that?

grammar.example: 안 그래도 = I was already going to

grammar.explanation: Idiom meaning 'to give someone a piece of your mind'
grammar.example: 한 소리 하고 싶었는데 = I wanted to say something

grammar.explanation: Sister-in-law (brother's wife, from a woman's perspective)

contents.original: 평소에 안 오는 건 그렇다 쳐, 명절도 그렇고 뭐 다 그래.
contents.pronunciation: Pyeongso-e an oneun geon geureota chyeo, myeongjeol-do geureoko mwo da geurae.
contents.translation: Not coming usually, fine. Same with holidays and everything else.

grammar.example: 그렇다 쳐 = let's say that's okay

contents.culture: 명절 (Korean holidays like Chuseok and Seollal) are major family gatherings. Not attending is considered a serious offense.

contents.original: 그런데 이번에는 아버지 회갑인데 와봐야 되는 거 아니니? 너무하잖아.
contents.pronunciation: Geureonde ibeon-eneun abeoji hoegab-inde wabwaya doeneun geo anini? Neomuhajana.
contents.translation: But this time it's Dad's 60th birthday. Shouldn't she have come? It's too much.

grammar.explanation: Expression meaning 'should at least try to'
grammar.example: 와봐야 되는 거 아니니 = shouldn't she come?

grammar.explanation: Expression meaning 'to go too far/be too much'

contents.culture: 회갑 (60th birthday) is a major milestone in Korean culture, traditionally celebrating completion of the 60-year zodiac cycle. Missing it is a serious family offense.

contents.translation: Yeah, you're right. She went too far.

contents.original: 그래, 잘 알아. 지가 너무한 거야.
contents.translation: Yeah, I know. She's the one who went too far.
So I'm going to divorce her.
Huh?

contents.original: 아버지, 엄마, 저 혜인이랑 이혼하려고 해요.
contents.pronunciation: Abeoji, eomma, jeo Hyein-irang ihon-haryeogo haeyo.
contents.translation: Dad, Mom, I'm going to divorce Hye-in.

grammar.example: 이혼하려고 해요 = I'm going to divorce

contents.translation: Huh? I'm sorry.

contents.original: 잠깐, 잠깐. 야, 너 설마 회갑에 안 온 거 때문에 이혼하겠다는 건 아니지?
contents.pronunciation: Jamkkan, jamkkan. Ya, neo seolma hoegab-e an on geo ttaemune ihon-hagetdaneun geon aniji?
contents.translation: Wait, wait. You're not saying you'll divorce her just because she didn't come to the birthday party, right?

grammar.example: 안 온 거 때문에 = because she didn't come

contents.original: 너 왜 그래? 회갑이 별거야? 생일이야. 매년 돌아오는 거라고.
contents.pronunciation: Neo wae geurae? Hoegab-i byeolgeoya? Saengil-iya. Maenyeon doraoneun georago.
contents.translation: What's wrong with you? Is a 60th birthday a big deal? It's just a birthday. It comes every year.

grammar.example: 별거야? = is it a big deal?

contents.culture: The sister tries to downplay the significance of the missed 회갑 to calm the situation, though traditionally it's considered very important.

contents.original: 그럼 당연하지. 야, 요새 누가 회갑을 세냐? 칠순도 그냥들 먹어, 백세시대야.
contents.pronunciation: Geureom dangyeonhaji. Ya, yosae nuga hoegab-eul senya? Chilsun-do geunyang-deul meogeo, baekse-sidae-ya.
contents.translation: Of course. Who even celebrates 60th birthdays these days? Even 70th birthdays are casual now—it's the age of living to 100.
contents.culture: With increased life expectancy in Korea, 회갑 (60th) has become less significant, while 칠순 (70th) and 팔순 (80th) are now the major milestones.

contents.original: 그런 거 때문에 그런 거 아니에요.
contents.pronunciation: Geureon geo ttaemune geureon geo anieyo.
contents.translation: It's not because of that.

grammar.example: 그런 거 아니에요 = it's not that

contents.original: 아니면 뭔데 그래. 그래도 이유가 있을 거 아니냐.
contents.pronunciation: Animyeon mweonde geurae. Geuraedo iyu-ga isseul geo aniya.
contents.translation: Then what is it? There must be a reason.

grammar.example: 있을 거 아니냐 = there must be, right?

contents.translation: Is there perhaps another woman...
Come on!
contents.culture: 아따 is a characteristic Jeolla Province dialect expression. Hyun-woo's family appears to be from this region.

contents.translation: No.
Then is the daughter-in-law seeing another man...
contents.culture: 새아가 is a warm, somewhat old-fashioned term for daughter-in-law, commonly used in rural areas.

contents.translation: Come on, really.

contents.original: 아니고요. 그냥 제가 좀 힘들어요. 사는 게 행복하지도 않고요.
contents.pronunciation: Anigoyo. Geunyang jega jom himdeureoyo. Saneun ge haengbok-hajido ankoyo.
contents.translation: No. I'm just having a hard time. Life isn't happy.

grammar.example: 사는 게 행복하지 않다 = life isn't happy

contents.original: 너 그게 뭔 이유 같지도 않은 이유여? 아버지는 뭐 맨날 행복한 줄 알아?
contents.pronunciation: Neo geuge mwon iyu gatjido aneun iyu-yeo? Abeoji-neun mwo maennal haengbok-han jul ara?
contents.translation: What kind of reason is that? You think Dad is happy all the time?

grammar.example: 이유 같지도 않은 이유 = a reason that doesn't even seem like a reason

contents.original: 그러지, 그러지. 너 아버지랑 만난 첫날부터 행복한 것이 아니여.
contents.pronunciation: Geureoji, geureoji. Neo abeoji-rang mannan cheonnal-buteo haengbok-han geosi aniyeo.
contents.translation: That's right. I haven't been happy since the first day I met your father.
Rather unhappy, actually.

contents.original: 아주 가끔 어쩌다가 가뭄에 콩 나듯이 하고 행복한 거?
contents.pronunciation: Aju gakkeum eojjeodaga gamum-e kong nadesui hago haengbok-han geo?
contents.translation: Only very rarely, like beans sprouting in a drought, you get happy?

grammar.explanation: Idiom meaning 'very rarely/once in a blue moon'
grammar.example: 가뭄에 콩 나듯이 = like beans in a drought

contents.culture: This idiom refers to how beans barely survive during drought—meaning something happens extremely rarely.

contents.original: 그냥 그거 하나로 버티고 사는 거고. 그것이 결혼이여 인생이고.
contents.pronunciation: Geunyang geugeo hanaro beotigo saneun geogo. Geugeos-i gyeolhon-iyeo insaeng-igo.
contents.translation: You just hold on with that one thing. That's marriage, that's life.

grammar.example: 버티고 사는 거 = living while enduring

contents.culture: This reflects the older Korean generation's view of marriage—endurance rather than happiness, a common theme in Korean family dramas.

contents.translation: You speak well.

grammar.explanation: Expression meaning 'to speak well' (can be sarcastic)

contents.original: 야, 막말로 내가 네 엄마를 막 그냥 사랑해서 사는 거 아니야?
contents.pronunciation: Ya, makmallo naega ne eomma-reul mak geunyang saranghaeseo saneun geo aniya?
contents.translation: Look, honestly, you think I live with your mom because I just love her?
What did you say?

contents.original: 내 말을 끝까지 들어봐. 사랑은 하지. 그렇지만 맨날 막 그냥 사랑만 하냐? 그럼 사람이 죽는다니까.
contents.pronunciation: Nae mar-eul kkeutkkaji deureobwa. Sarang-eun haji. Geureochiman maennal mak geunyang sarang-man hanya? Geureom saram-i jungneundanikka.
contents.translation: Listen to me until the end. I do love her. But can you just love all the time? You'd die.

grammar.example: 죽는다니까 = I'm telling you, you'd die

contents.translation: Okay, okay. Be careful with your words.

grammar.explanation: Dialect expression meaning 'be careful with words'
grammar.example: 말순강 하쇼 = watch what you say

contents.original: 이거 봐라, 현우야. 40여 년을 같이 산 엄마, 아버지도 이렇게 이심전심이 안 된다.
contents.pronunciation: Igeo bwara, Hyeonu-ya. Sasip-yeo nyeon-eul gachi san eomma, abeoji-do ireoke isimjeonsim-i an doenda.
contents.translation: Look, Hyun-woo. Even your mom and dad who lived together for 40 years can't read each other's minds.

grammar.example: 이심전심이 안 된다 = can't connect heart-to-heart

contents.culture: 이심전심 (以心傳心) is a Buddhist-origin idiom meaning 'from heart to heart' or 'telepathic understanding' between close people.

contents.translation: Not at all.

grammar.explanation: Adverb meaning 'not at all/not one bit'
grammar.example: 하나도 안 되지 = not at all

contents.translation: Oh, goodness.

contents.original: 무슨 말씀이신지 알아요. 그런데 저 정말 충분히 생각하고 결정해서 말씀드린 거예요.
contents.pronunciation: Museun malsseum-isinji arayo. Geureonde jeo jeongmal chungbunhi saenggak-hago gyeoljeong-haeseo malsseum-deurin geoyeyo.
contents.translation: I understand what you're saying. But I've thought about this enough and made my decision.
I'm going to divorce. I'm sorry.
I have something to say.

grammar.example: 할 말이 있어 = I have something to say

contents.translation: Me first.
Huh?

contents.original: 나도 할 말이 있으니까 나부터 하겠다고.
contents.pronunciation: Nado hal mal-i isseunikka nabuteo hagetdago.
contents.translation: I have something to say too, so I'll go first.
Okay. Go ahead.

grammar.example: 먼저 해 = go ahead/do it first

contents.original: 나 죽는데 석 달 정도 남았대.
contents.pronunciation: Na jungneunde seok dal jeongdo namattae.
contents.translation: I have about three months left to live.

grammar.example: 남았대 = they say I have left

grammar.explanation: Native Korean number + month counter = 3 months

contents.culture: This is the dramatic twist—Hye-in reveals her terminal illness just as Hyun-woo announces divorce.

contents.translation: What?

grammar.explanation: Expression of shock asking for clarification

contents.original: 나 아까 갈 데 있다고 했잖아. 병원 갔었어.
contents.pronunciation: Na akka gal de itdago haetjana. Byeongwon gasseosseo.
contents.translation: I said I had somewhere to go earlier. I went to the hospital.

grammar.explanation: Reminder of what was said before
grammar.example: 있다고 했잖아 = I said there was, remember?

contents.original: 거기서 의사가 그러더라고 내가 죽는다고. 석 달 정도 남았다고.
contents.pronunciation: Geogiseo uisa-ga geureodeorag naega jungneundago. Seok dal jeongdo namattago.
contents.translation: The doctor there told me I'm dying. About three months left.
What do you mean?

grammar.example: 그게 무슨 말이야 = what does that mean?

contents.original: 무슨 말이긴 말 그대로야. 내가 석 달밖에 못 산대, 의사가.
contents.pronunciation: Museun marigein mal geudaeroya. Naega seok dal-bakke mot sandae, uisa-ga.
contents.translation: What do I mean? Exactly what I said. The doctor says I only have three months.

grammar.example: 말 그대로야 = it's exactly as I said
석 달밖에 못 산대 = can only live 3 months

contents.original: 난 할 얘기 끝났어. 당신은 무슨 얘기인데?
contents.pronunciation: Nan hal yaegi kkeunnasseo. Dangsin-eun museun yaegi-inde?
contents.translation: I'm done with what I had to say. What did you want to say?

grammar.explanation: Expression meaning 'finished saying what needed to be said'
grammar.example: 할 얘기 끝났어 = I'm done talking

contents.translation: What?
You said you had something to say. What is it?

contents.original: 지금 내 얘기가 중요한 건 아닌 것 같은데.
contents.pronunciation: Jigeum nae yaegi-ga jungyohan geon anin geot gateunde.
contents.translation: I don't think what I was going to say is important right now.

grammar.example: 아닌 것 같은데 = it seems like it's not

contents.translation: Tell me what it is. You have something to say.

contents.original: 아니, 나는 그러니까 내가 무슨 말을...
contents.pronunciation: Ani, naneun geureonikka naega museun mar-eul...
contents.translation: No, I mean, what I was going to say...
Yeah.

contents.original: 내가 무슨 말을 하려고 했냐면 내가.
contents.pronunciation: Naega museun mar-eul haryeogo haennyamyeon naega.
contents.translation: What I was going to say was...

grammar.explanation: Pattern meaning 'what I was going to do was'
grammar.example: 하려고 했냐면 = what I was going to say

contents.translation: Yeah.
I'm sorry.

contents.original: 오늘 일도 그렇고 그동안 혜인이 너한테 정말 미안한 일이 많았다.
contents.pronunciation: Oneul il-do geureoko geudong-an Hyeini neohante jeongmal mianan ir-i manhatda.
contents.translation: Today and all this time, there's been so much I should apologize for.

grammar.example: 오늘 일도 그렇고 = today's matter too

grammar.explanation: Adverb meaning 'during this time/all this while'

contents.original: 앞으로는 그런 일 없을 거다. 내가 진짜 잘하겠다.
contents.pronunciation: Apeuro-neun geureon il eopseul geoda. Naega jinjja jalhhagetda.
contents.translation: From now on, that won't happen. I'll really do better.

contents.original: 그 말을 하려고 그랬는데 그런데 네가 죽는다니 석 달이라니. 그게 말이 돼?
contents.pronunciation: Geu mar-eul haryeogo geuraenneunde geureonde nega jungneundani seok daritani. Geuge mar-i dwae?
contents.translation: That's what I was going to say. But you're dying? Three months? Does that make sense?

grammar.example: 그게 말이 돼? = does that make sense?

contents.original: 나더러 너 없이 살라고? 그게 가능하긴 해.
contents.pronunciation: Nadeoreo neo eopsi sallago? Geuge ganeung-hagin hae.
contents.translation: You want me to live without you? Is that even possible?

contents.original: 나 지금 너무 기가 막혀서 무슨 말을 해야 할지.
contents.pronunciation: Na jigeum neomu giga makhyeoseo museun mar-eul haeya halji.
contents.translation: I'm so stunned right now I don't know what to say.
Really?
Yes, you fool.
contents.culture: 바보야 here is used affectionately, showing that despite everything, there's still love between them.

contents.translation: I love you, Hong Hye-in.
contents.culture: This is a pivotal moment—despite wanting divorce, Hyun-woo confesses his love when faced with losing her forever.

contents.translation: I love you.
contents.culture: 사랑한다 is a more emphatic, declarative form than 사랑해. It's often used in emotional, dramatic moments.
